title: Intel shows off 10nm Cannon Lake CPU, declaring Moore's Law isn't dead | Trusted Reviews
description:
![](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg) Credit: Intel

**Intel’s 10nm Cannon Lake next-generation CPU is a reality, with the
chipmaker showing off a wafer of the processors in China.**

At China’s technology and Manufacturing Day event, Intel’s senior fellow Mark
Bohr took to the stage with a wafer of Cannon Lake CPUs, demonstrating that
Intel’s much-delayed chip based on the transistor dense 10nm fabrication
process is out of the development phase, with the company touting improved
transistor performance over its previous chips based on the 14nm fabrication
process.

With Cannon Lake, Intel is boasting that it is advancing Moore’s Law, which in
rough terms states that the performance of CPUs will double every year.

“Intel manufacturing processes advance according to Moore’s Law, delivering
ever more functionality and performance, improved energy efficiency and lower
cost-per-transistor with each generation,” said Stacy Smith, group president
of manufacturing, operations and sales.

However, there’s an argument that Intel’s more recent chips, such as its Kaby
Lake, Skylake and Broadwell generation Core i processors, have injected only
minor performance and power efficiency hikes over previous generation chips,
which didn’t really offer the performance boosts Moore’s Law promises.

That being said, Intel has been stuck on the 14nm architecture for several CPU
generations, so there’s potential that by going down to the 10nm process,
Intel’s Cannon Lake CPUs could deliver a boost in power PC and gaming
enthusiasts have been waiting for.

Intel needs to keep pushing the envelope with its CPUs, as thanks to the debut
of AMD’s [Ryzen 7](https://www.trustedreviews.com/reviews/amd-ryzen-7-1800x),
Ryzen 5 and Ryzen 3 CPUs, alongside its high-end
[Threadripper](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/amd-threadripper-release-
date-price-specs-3231747) chip, Intel is facing strong competition once more
in the desktop and laptop CPU arena.
